sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Here are our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Europe's coronavirus death toll is on course to pass 2 million by March, the WHO warns, as a deadly COVID wave continues to sweep the continent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: North Macedonia declares three days of national mourning after a bus crash in Bulgaria kills at least 45 people, including 12 children. He's accused of mass murder and war crimes, but ex-Iranian official Hamid Nouri slams the charges as lies as he takes the stand in Stockholm. And several Hungarian media organisations have defied a controversial law by publishing an LGBT educational campaign.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: law by publishing an LGBT educational campaign.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to the programme. The World Health Organisation says Europe has missed the boat in preventing a fourth wave of COVID-19 and is now facing an extra 700,000 deaths by March 1st.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: That would push the death toll for the continent to over 2 million people. The WHO says if Europe fails to contain rising infection numbers, health systems across the continent will come under high and extreme stress.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: It says the Delta variant, unvaccinated people and waning immunity are driving the surge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: It's urged countries to get people fully vaccinated and offer boosters to those who need it, as well as the following strict hygiene guidelines. The European Commission has released eye-opening data that suggests a higher vaccination rate against COVID-19 equates to a lower number of deaths caused by the virus. In Ireland, with 93% of the adult population fully vaccinated, its death rate over a two-week period is 15 per 1 million of the population, while Bulgaria, with a vaccine uptake of just 29%, has recorded 325 deaths per 1 million of population.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Following Monday's national lockdown, Austrian health officials say there's been a surge in vaccine uptake. Austria is the first European country to make vaccines mandatory and just over 65% of the adult population have been double jabbed. One Vienna vaccine center said the number of first doses administered this week has risen by 10 to 15 percent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The vaccination rate has increased here in this centre and across Vienna, but also in all of Austria.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Two weeks ago, we had around 1,000 vaccinations per day here in the Austria centre.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Right now, we have reached 12,000 to 13,000 daily vaccinations in this centre alone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But we are also noticing a clear increase in vaccinations in all other areas, like our mobile vaccination booths and vaccination buses.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Let's cross over to Strasbourg to speak to our correspondent there, Shona Murray.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Shona, good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The WHO says Europe's COVID death toll is likely to pass 2 million by March. Epidemiologists saying there's a clear link between rising case numbers and low vaccination rates. What's the level of concern where you are right now? Oh, that's right, Paul. We saw those statistics that you mentioned there in relation to the correlation between countries with high levels of vaccination and fewer deaths, and then the opposite in the fact that countries like bulgaria with 29 vaccinated and well over 300 deaths per 1 million i'm joined now by peter liza who's a german mep peter you're on the health committee i mean okay first and foremost how do we get the rest of the rest of europe vaccinated there's a supply there there, but countries like Bulgaria with 29% vaccinated, Austria 64%, and parts of Germany not that well vaccinated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: Yeah, this is unfortunately true.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: This is also our biggest problem.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: There are other problems.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: The protection rate of the vaccine goes down and we have the Delta variant.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: So also twice vaccinated people should be careful.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: But it's very clear in my country, Germany, the regions where we have a high vaccination are much better off.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: And that's also true for Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: So I think it's important, of course, to continue to speak, to explain people, to take their concerns seriously.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: But we also need to go a step further. I think we need to have much more use of the certificate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: And people that decide not to be vaccinated cannot get the same rights and freedoms than others, because they are a serious threat to our health care system and that needs to be implemented much stronger all over Europe. I mean your own health minister Jens Spahn had some very stark words yesterday that people in Germany are either going to be recovering, vaccinated or dead. I mean do you think that was a bit harsh or is that the scenario we're seeing now because of Delta? It was exaggerated because by reasons we somehow don't know, even people that have close contact to somebody that is infected don't infect themselves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: That's always a question of coincidence and factors that we don't know.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: But there's a serious risk and I would advise everybody to be vaccinated because the risk of being seriously infected is very high.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: So exaggerated but not completely wrong. I mean you're obviously a medical doctor by profession.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We heard from the head of AstraZeneca today that said that Europe is facing the wave it is because many member states dropped use of AstraZeneca.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Does that ring true from what you know about the vaccines?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: Unfortunately, I have to say that's again another nonsense from the head of AstraZeneca because we have enough other vaccine, mRNA vaccine is available.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: And unfortunately, we see now that the problem that I described, that the protection is going down after some months, is more serious in AstraZeneca than in the other vaccines. So I would now recommend people to get the mRNA vaccine or the combination first dose AstraZeneca, second dose mRNA vaccine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: But the problem we have is definitely not linked to the non-use of AstraZeneca, definitely not.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: OK, Peter Lise, thank you very much for joining us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And back to you in studio, Paul.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Many thanks, Shona.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: With Christmas just around the corner, Austrian businesses are warning of the economic hit the national lockdown will have. Let's speak to Rainer Will, CEO of the Austrian Retail Association. Many thanks for taking the time to speak to us. Considering the current COVID situation in Austria, did the government have any other choice than to lock down?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: There are always different choices.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And the biggest problem was that the political leaders missed out to set up a vaccine campaign during the summer.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The Austrian Retail Association set it up, but without public funds, it was not possible to reach everybody.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And moreover, the opposition party, which is the biggest one, is a vaccination opponent, and therefore it was hard. And now we have to really set up hard measures. And the obligation and also the obligation for the vaccine is one of that measure. And the second is the hard lockdown. And Austria is also the first country in Western Europe who sets up a hard lockdown since the vaccination was rolled out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And it's the only country where also retail businesses are affected by the lockdown.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: It's a hard lockdown, as you say, Black Friday this week, pre-Christmas shopping as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: What's been the impact for your members?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: It's a hard impact. We see that 2.7 billion euro will be lost alone with the retail shops and in total we will lose for the whole Austrian economy around 6 billion euro. So we estimate that about 10,000 retail stores are at insolvency risk and moreover 10,000 jobs at risk. So we estimate that in the whole total of the Austrian economy, 400,000 employees will be put on short-term work. So it is mostly important that we know that quick help is good help and therefore it has to be unbureaucratic and fast that all these small and medium enterprises will still be safe you know in short time so is the government doing enough in your view in my view it has to be more it has to be more precisely to not support businesses which got reduced or shut down already because there is a measure comparison to the companies with the most jobs. And therefore, there's much more to do and it is not yet done. Rainerville, a CEO of the Austrian Retail Association. Many thanks for your time. North Macedonia has declared three days of mourning

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: due to the bus accident, which killed at least 45 passengers, including 12 children, in western Bulgaria.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: The Shkopy-bound bus was carrying tourists returning from a trip to Turkey. Seven people survived and have been taken to hospitals with burns. The North Macedonian Prime Minister said an investigation into the causes of the crash is underway.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: I will leave it to the Bulgarian experts to investigate and analyse what's the reason behind this tragedy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And those who survived have their own memories of what happened.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: The only thing we can do now is to say sorry for the losses and for the grief of the families who lost their relatives.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Bulgaria is working hard with all institutions responsible for the investigation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: Now a number of media organizations in Hungary have defied a controversial law banning the portrayal of homosexuality to children.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: TV channels and magazines have joined an LGBT campaign under the hashtag the same. Matthew in the Cube has the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well Paul, this campaign was launched last week in collaboration with International Children's Rights Days by an NGO known as the Foundation for Freedom Families.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: This campaign essentially features a short video featuring two talkative puppets under the hashtag Udjanaas, literally translating as hashtag the same.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Organizers say they hope this campaign will promote the discrimination that LGBT families and their children are facing in Hungary and raise awareness for this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: For example, you have a country where gay marriage is not recognised and adoption rights are not allowed for same-sex couples.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: In June, Hungarian MPs also passed a controversial law banning the portrayal of homosexuality and gender reassignment to anyone aged under 18.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Essentially companies and media organisations could face fines if they were deemed to promote LGBT content to children.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So this bill seemingly outlaws that hashtag the same campaign that was launched last week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: But despite the threat of fines, a number of organisations and media groups have said they will be sharing it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: According to the organisation, more than 200 posters, some on billboards like this one or in magazines, will be featured.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And a number of major television companies, the likes of MTV, Comedy Central and the Paramount Network, have all said that they will feature that social media video.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: This is the latest development in a long-running dispute in the EU when it comes to anti-LGBT policies in Hungary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: For example, the European Commission said after that law that was launched in Hungary that it would be investigating the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: This after Ursula von der Leyen described that bill as a shame.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Now, the Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban and his ruling Conservative Fidesz party have said that that law was meant to tackle paedophilia, and he says that they will hold a referendum on the law.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: But this is certainly a long-running dispute, Paul, and you can certainly see with that hashtag, the same campaign, organisers are still trying to raise awareness about the LGBT community in Hungary, despite the fact and the bans from authorities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Matthew, many thanks for that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Still to come, what now for farming in the EU, after MEPs finally agree to reform the bloc's common agricultural policy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews tonight. A very warm welcome back to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Hamid Nouri, who's accused of murder, crimes against humanity and war crimes,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: has told a Swedish court that the accusations against him are lies. The charges relate to his job as an assistant to the deputy prosecutor of a prison near Tehran in the 1980s.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: He's said to have taken prisoners to death chambers, but Nuri rejects the charges.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Human rights groups claim about 5,000 prisoners were killed under the orders of Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei at the end of the Iran-Iraq war between 1918 and 1988.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Let's speak to our reporter pair bergs for

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Zneiberg who's in Stockholm for us pair great to see you a large crowd of protesters gathered outside court today why were they there well hi good evening Paul basically there were quite a lot of people here several hundred people in fact you're gathered here outside the Stockholm District Court just behind me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And basically I met people from Switzerland, from France, from Albania.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They traveled from all over Europe to be here today for the first day of Hamid Nouri's testimony.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And basically they told me that they want to be a voice for the voiceless.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I met one woman from a victim's organization saying this was a historic day.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: I also met a really young girl who told me that her father was imprisoned back in 1988. He was in fact tortured in prison and some of his cellmates, the other prisoners there at the prison, were executed. Here's what they told me. When I have been inside and seen him and when I hear his voice, it's really painful because he has been hurting my dad and my dad's friends that I have seen in front of me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: That just makes me so, I don't know, I feel so weak and so powerless to not be able to do something when he's standing in front of us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: For me personally, it's a really emotional feeling also to be here, to stand here, where history is written.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It means that the people of Iran and the resistance will not give up until they bring all the masterminds of this crime against humanity and genocide to justice.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I think what has happened is that the people of the world are now seeing what happened in Iran.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And one has to bear in mind, the 1988 massacre and the crime against humanity has continued ever since.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: NICK SCHIFRIN And, as you can tell, these people, they don't only blame Mohammed Nouri for these mass executions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: In fact, they blame the very top political sphere in Iran, the people at the very top, the people at the power, at the helm of Iran's government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: And, Per, Hamid Nouri took the stand earlier today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: What did he have to say?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well, Paul, basically he took the stand here inside Stockholm's district court where they even have a mock-up of the prison and a little paper note that says execution chamber pointing to a specific room however Hamanuri he says that these accusations they're just a work of fiction he's just a family father deeply devoted she a Muslim civil servant to trying to help everyone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: He also went on to say that the people who've been testifying here in court, they didn't only, they haven't just insulted him, they've insulted the state of Iran, the Iranian people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So he went on to defend Ahmadinejad.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: He went on to defend Raisi, the current president who is accused of being one of the four people at the helm of this death squad.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: He also went on to defend Khomeini.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So he says that all these accusations are just basically false, Paul.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Per, many thanks for that update.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Per, Borgsvore Nyberg there reporting for us from Stockholm.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: The European Parliament has given the green light to controversial reforms of the Common Agricultural Policy. The changes, which have an impact on a budget worth more than 380 billion euros, are designed to help tackle climate change, but environmentalists say it is a case of greenwashing. Christopher Pitchers reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: washing. Christopher Pitchers reports. CHRISTOPHER PITCHERS, After years of negotiations, MEPs have finally approved reforms to the E.U.'s common agricultural policy. This latest round of changes is intended to be more climate-friendly and fairer to small farms and young farmers. But for Thijs Bullens, a 30-year-old farmer who runs an organic farm, The reforms mean nothing to him.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Once again, we get nothing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: This cap reform makes the big farmers just bigger than before.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We are giving money to the rich with this cap.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I don't know if the people of the European Union understand this. We are giving public money to people who already have a lot of money.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thijs and his partners produce around 60 kinds of vegetables.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But they only receive roughly 2,500 euros per year in European aid.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Anna, a Belgian producer, deplores the difficulties faced by new, younger farmers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: For young people like us, it's already very difficult to set up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We don't have any land, we don't have a farmhouse, we don't have any buildings.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We work with plastic tents, we build our own sheds with containers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We do what we can.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It's fine sometimes, but in fact, I think we'd prefer to work in barns with things like smooth concrete, for example.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: For the representatives of the main agricultural organizations and cooperatives, it's time to move forward.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Cap reform negotiations opened in 2018, and they say must now come to an end.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, it's never enough.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: If you ask any stakeholder group, we all have our ambitions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But this is about the compromise that now has been reached.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We do not get everything for European agriculture.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It's a compromise that we have to live with.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: However, we consider this is a good compromise, where most of the objectives have been addressed, and we are committed to it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: MALCOLM BRABANT, European Commission on Agricultural Reforms, Many MEPs have been vocal in their criticism of the latest CAP reforms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But for one of the main legislators on the issue, the changes bring a level of certainty.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: JOSEPH BOUCHARD, President, French Foreign Ministry of the United States of America For the first time since the beginning of the CAP reform, we will have more regulation than deregulation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And the pandemic has shown us once again that markets, and in particular agricultural markets, are structurally unstable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And when you have unstable markets, you need regulation and crisis management tools to guarantee farmers' incomes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The cap represents around a third of the European budget and nearly 400 billion euros.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The latest reforms will come into force in 2023.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Christopher Pichas, Euronews, Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Still to come, it's been a hit in France and for international audiences on Netflix.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Now, comedy Call My Agent has taken Hollywood by storm.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: More after the break.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: It was first shown here in France,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: but has since gone on to be a huge hit on Netflix and now the series Call My Agent has been recognised by Hollywood.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Judith Prescott has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: It was a hit on streaming giant Netflix and now the French series Die Pourson, renamed Call My Agent for the English-speaking public, has won an international Emmy award for best comedy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The series tracks the events of the fictional ASK agency and features a host of real-life famous faces such as Charlotte Gainsbourg and Isabelle Huppert as their clients.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The writers and producers of the series were in New York for the ceremony.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We didn't even think it would be a national success, honestly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Often people told us, but it won't interest many people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's about a small Parisian elite, a small world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: How can it be universal?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And that is also a source of great pride.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's that, through the small world, we still have managed to discover themes that I gave the impression speak to a lot of people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The series has received worldwide acclaim with adaptations currently being prepared in Turkey, South Korea, India and the UK featuring their own homegrown stars.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: We leave you with a no comment from the Catalonian National Museum in Barcelona, where over 650 pieces of Antonio Gaudi's work have gone on display.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: Thanks for watching Euronews Tonight. La ciudad de Badajoz Gracias.
